title: NSA Data Center Power Consumption and Bandwidth Usage

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NSA Data Center Power Consumption and Bandwidth Usage
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear FOIA Officer,

I am writing to request information under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 U.S.C. § 552, regarding the bandwidth usage and power consumption of the National Security Agency's (NSA) data centers. Specifically, I am requesting data on the gigawatt power consumption and bandwidth usage of the NSA's data centers listed below for the past three years:

Utah Data Center in Bluffdale, Utah
Georgia Cryptologic Center in Augusta, Georgia
Texas Cryptologic Center in San Antonio, Texas
NSA Hawaii Cryptologic Center in Honolulu, Hawaii

To ensure a complete and thorough response, I would like to clarify that when I use the term "any" in my request, I am using it in the broadest sense to mean all records that meet the criteria specified in my request. I am not limiting my request to a specific type or subset of records, but rather seeking all records that contain the requested information.

In addition, I would like to request that any responsive records be provided in a format that is accessible to individuals with disabilities, in accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Section 508 standards.

With that clarification, I request the following information:

Any and all documents, including but not limited to reports, spreadsheets, or data tables, that contain information about the power consumption of the above-listed NSA data centers, including:

a. The total amount of power consumed by each data center on an annual basis for each of the past three years.

b. The sources of energy used (e.g., coal, natural gas, renewable sources) for each data center for each of the past three years.

c. Any efforts or initiatives by the NSA to reduce energy consumption or improve energy efficiency at each data center, including any plans or programs in place for each of the past three years.

Any and all documents, including but not limited to reports, spreadsheets, or data tables, that contain information about the bandwidth usage of the above-listed NSA data centers, including:

a. The total amount of data transmitted and received by each data center on an annual basis for each of the past three years.

b. The sources and types of data transmitted and received (e.g., voice, text, images, video) for each data center for each of the past three years.

c. Any efforts or initiatives by the NSA to reduce bandwidth usage or improve network efficiency at each data center, including any plans or programs in place for each of the past three years.

Any and all correspondence, including emails and memos, between NSA officials and other federal agencies, contractors, or private companies, regarding the energy usage or efficiency or bandwidth usage or efficiency of the above-listed NSA data centers, including any information related to the power consumption or bandwidth usage of these facilities.

Any and all records, including but not limited to contracts or agreements, related to the procurement or purchase of energy or network equipment for the above-listed NSA data centers for each of the past three years.

Any and all records related to the maintenance or repair of equipment or systems related to energy usage or efficiency or bandwidth usage or efficiency for the above-listed NSA data centers for each of the past three years.

In order to ensure that all responsive records are included, please conduct a search that includes all files, documents, and electronic data created or received by the NSA from January 1, 2018, to the date of your processing this FOIA request. If any responsive records are exempt from disclosure, please provide a detailed justification for each exemption and segregate any non-exempt portions for release.

Furthermore, I would like to cite the following case law in support of this FOIA request:

In Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington v. U.S. Dep't of Energy, 923 F. Supp. 2d 237, 242-44 (D.D.C. 2013), the court held that energy usage data of government facilities was not protected by Exemption 3 or Exemption 4 of the FOIA and must be disclosed.
In Natural Res. Def. Council v. U.S. Dep't of Energy, 191 F. Supp. 2d41, 54 (D.D.C. 2002), the court held that a request for information on energy usage and efficiency of government facilities is not unduly burdensome and must be processed under the FOIA.

In order to prevent the use of a Glomar response, I would like to state that the existence of responsive records is not classified or exempt from disclosure under FOIA. I am requesting information that is not classified or sensitive in nature, and the release of which would not harm national security or any ongoing investigation or operation.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Policies and Procedures for Transcribing Immigration Court Hearings for Appeal

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Policies and Procedures for Transcribing Immigration Court Hearings for Appeal
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Requested Info:

On behalf of my non-profit organizational employer, Capital Area Immigrants' Rights (CAIR) Coalition, I request any and all internal directives or policy guidance issued by the Department of Justice’s Executive Office for Immigration Review (“EOIR”) regarding EOIR’s process for contracting out, obtaining, and reviewing transcripts of hearings before the Immigration Judge (IJ) for review by the Board of Immigration Appeals ("BIA"), as required by the BIA Practice Manual Chapter 4.2(f). 

Specifically, I request any current internal directives, manuals, memos, policy guidance, or other documents related to:  
1.	Processes and procedures for assigning Digital Audio Recording(s) (“DAR”) to transcription contractors, including but not limited to Free State Reporting, Inc. (“Free State”), to be transcribed for purposes of creating the Record of Proceeding(s) (“ROP”) for review by the BIA (see attached document for previous guidance, last updated in 2015)
2.	Any training, education, or certification EOIR requires of transcribers or the transcription companies with which EOIR contracts;
3.	Any policies and guidance regarding EOIR oversight and quality control over the transcription process, including any quality control checklists used by EOIR staff; 
4.	Any policies and procedures regarding the steps EOIR takes when the transcription contractor sends back a defective or otherwise unsatisfactory transcript, for example one with significant typos, indiscernible notations, or other errors, including any processes for returning a defective or unsatisfactory transcript to the transcription contractor to be re-transcribed;
5.	Any policies and procedures regarding the steps EOIR and/or the transcription contractor takes when the DAR is partially or totally inaudible such that it cannot be properly transcribed.

Request for Waiver of Fees:

CAIR Coalition requests that EOIR waive all fees associated with this request. Such a request is warranted on the grounds that disclosure of the information contained in the requested record is in the public interest and is “likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requestor.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii); 28 C.F.R. § 16.10(k)(1). Disclosure of this information is in the public interest of understanding how and when immigration proceedings are transcribed for appellate purposes. CAIR Coalition is a nonprofit organization recognized as a 501(c)(3) entity by the Internal Revenue Service that provides legal services and information to immigrant populations and information to the public on immigration issues.

Disclosure of the requested information also will contribute to “understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons.” 28 C.F.R. § 16.10(k)(2)(ii)(B). The requested information will be used to better equip pro bono practitioners—both at CAIR Coalition and at other pro bono organizations—representing non-citizens before EOIR.  As a provider of legal services to non-citizens, CAIR Coalition has the necessary expertise, capacity, and intention to review, analyze, and synthesize this information and make it accessible to a broad audience of attorneys and clients in immigration proceedings. In addition to the requested information being publicly available on Muckrock, the platform through which I am filing this FOIA request, CAIR Coalition has the capacity to convey the information to a broad audience on CAIR Coalition's website, which receives more than 10,000 monthly visitors. CAIR Coalition also will circulate a summary of information disclosed through this request on its listservs, in which approximately 2,500 attorneys participate. Additionally, CAIR Coalition shares information in its newsletter, which is directly distributed to 6,000 recipients.

CAIR Coalition is also “a representative of the news media” within the meaning of the statute and applicable regulations. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii) (defined as “any . . . entity that gathers information of potential interest to a segment of the public, uses its editorial skills to turn the raw materials into a distinct work, and distributes that work to an audience,”); Nat. Sec. Archive v. Dep’t of Defense, 880 F.2d 1381, 1397 (D.C. Cir. 1989) (same); Electronic Privacy Info. Ctr. v. Dep’t of Defense, 241 F. Supp. 2d 5 (D.D.C. 2003) (non-profit that published information in a wide variety of sources on topics of privacy and civil liberties qualified as representative of news media for FOIA purposes). Given that FOIA's fee waiver requirements are to be “liberally construed in favor of waivers for noncommercial requesters,” a waiver of all fees is justified and warranted in this instance. See Judicial Watch, Inc. v. Rossotti, 326 F.3d 1309, 1312 (D.C. Cir. 2003) (quotation omitted).

Request for Expedited Processing:

CAIR Coalition requests Track 1 expedited treatment for this FOIA request. There is a compelling need for expedited processing, namely, an “urgency to inform the public concerning the actual or alleged Federal Government activity.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II). CAIR Coalition is currently briefing a Petition for Review at the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in which defects in the transcript present a central issue on appeal. Information about the transcription process will help CAIR Coalition articulate legal arguments about our client's due process right to meaningful appellate review and advocate for broadly applicable law and procedures to be employed when a defective transcript is hindering review. Petitioner's opening brief to the Fourth Circuit is due on June 6, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ian Austin Rose

title: Request for Records Related to Helicopter Flight with Tail Number NY120NY

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Request for Records Related to Helicopter Flight with Tail Number NY120NY
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Records Access Officer
New York City Department of Environmental Protection
59-17 Junction Blvd.
19th Floor
Flushing, NY 11373

Dear Records Access Officer,

I am writing to request access to detailed records related to the helicopter flight with tail number NY120NY that occurred in the jurisdiction of the New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) on May 9th, 2023, pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA).

FOIA was enacted to ensure that the public has access to information held by the government, subject to certain limited exemptions. The Supreme Court has recognized that FOIA "reflects our nation's fundamental commitment to open government" (New York Times Co. v. United States, 1971) and that the government has a "heavy burden" to prove that information should be kept secret (id.). FOIA's exemptions are to be narrowly construed, and the government has the burden of proving that the information requested is exempt from disclosure (United States Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 1989).

To ensure that this request is as comprehensive as possible, I am requesting the following records:

Flight Logs: Please provide all records related to the helicopter flight, including but not limited to flight logs that detail the flight paths and actions taken during the flight. These records should include information about the time of takeoff and landing, the duration of the flight, and any stops made during the flight.
Video Logs: Please provide all video logs captured by the helicopter's onboard cameras during the flight. These logs should include all footage captured during the flight, including footage of any stops made during the flight.
Transmissions: Please provide all records of transmissions between the helicopter and ground personnel or any other parties during the flight. These records should include any audio recordings or written transcripts of these transmissions.
Maintenance and Safety Records: Please provide any records related to the helicopter's maintenance and safety inspections, as well as the pilot's certifications and qualifications.
Weather and Air Traffic Information: Please provide all weather and air traffic information that was available to the pilot during the flight.
Pilot Logbook: Please provide the pilot's logbook for the flight, which should include the pilot's flight hours, certifications, and qualifications.
Flight Plan: Please provide the flight plan for the helicopter flight, including any revisions made to the plan before or during the flight.
Communications between DEP and Other Agencies: Please provide any records of communications between the DEP and other agencies related to the helicopter flight.
Body-Worn Camera Footage: Please provide any body-worn camera footage that was recorded by DEP personnel during the flight, if available.
Records of Stops or Interactions: Please provide any records related to any stops or interactions that occurred during the flight, including but not limited to any reports or logs of interactions with members of the public or other agencies.
The courts have held that agencies must conduct a "reasonable search" for records responsive to a FOIA request, and that the adequacy of an agency's search is to be judged by the reasonableness of the efforts made, not by the results achieved (Electronic Privacy Information Center v. United States Department of Homeland Security, 2006). I would like to request that these records be provided to me in an electronic format, if possible, to reduce the cost and time associated with printing and mailing.

If any portion of these records is exempt from disclosure under FOIA, please provide an explanation of the basis for the exemption, consistent with the courts' holding that FOIA's exemptions are to be narrowly construed and that the government has the burden of proving that information should be kept secret.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Portland Shotspotter

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Portland Shotspotter
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1) All records of scheduled meetings between ShotSpotter or SoundThinking representatives and Portland police, including the chief/commissioner since November 1, 2022 including any written or recorded notes from the meetings.

2) All records of scheduled meetings between ShotSpotter/SoundThinking representatives and Portland police public information or media relations department since November 1, 2022 included any written or recorded notes from the meetings.

3) All email exchanges -- including incoming messages, outgoing messages, forwards, and attachments -- between the department's chief/commissioner and other police officers and ShotSpotter/SoundThinking representatives since November 1, 2022. ShotSpotter representatives can be identified by searching the department's email system for addresses ending in "@shotspotter.com" or "@soundthinking.com"

4) All emails exchanges–including incoming messages, outgoing messages, forwards, and attachments–between the department's public information and/or media relations staff members and ShotSpotter/SoundThinking representatives since November 1, 2021. ShotSpotter representatives can be identified by searching the department's email system for addresses ending in "@shotspotter.com" or "@soundthinking.com"

5) All instructional materials, presentations and presentation materials (including recorded video and audio, PowerPoint files, prepared remarks, and slides formats), and other guidance on police use of Shotspotter/SoundThinking. This includes A) any notes taking during meetings that discussed the use of Shotspotter/SoundThinking, B) any explanations (whether internally or externally generated) of how this program works, and C) any other document that has been used to help explain the use of this program to any party, including internal documentation, public relations materials, and executive summaries.

I ask that all fees be waived as I intend to use the requested records to further public understanding of government functions and not for any commercial purpose.

In the event that you choose to withhold or redact the records, I ask that you provide a detailed explanation of the statutory and/or case law upon which each rejection or redaction is based.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Johana Bhuiyan

communications.subject: You have an invoice available :: S283207-050923
communications.communication:
RE:  Public Records Request#: S283207-050923 
 
Dear Johana Bhuiyan, 
 
 PAYMENT DUE 
 
The City may be the custodian of at least some of the requested public records and a payment is due to continue processing this request. Please log into the Portland Public Records Request Center to pay these fees. 
 
Fees include research time to locate and analyze the requested records, even if no records are located or if the requested records are determined to be exempt from disclosure. We will not be working on your request until we receive the payment. 
 
Please log in to the Portland Public Records Request Center (copy and right click this link to open it in your browser) and make a payment on this request. 
 
You may pay by electronic check or credit card by going to "My Public Records Request Center" and select "View My Invoices." Then scroll to find your open invoice and select "Make Payment." Follow the screen prompts to make a payment. 
 
Due to the current state of emergency, most City offices are not staffed. Consequently, if you mail a check it could delay the response time and it is preferable that you use the online payment portal to make an electronic payment. However, if you need to mail a check, please reply to this message and ask for the correct address. Please be sure and provide your Reference Number (S283207-050923) on your check. 
 
Please be advised that pursuant to ORS 192.329(3)(b) and (4)(b), your public records request will be closed if payment is not received within sixty (60) days of this invoice. 
 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
City of Portland Public Records Responder 
 
 
 *Please note that you will need to disable your pop-up blocker on your browser's settings in order to make an online payment.
*Please see this Answer for more information:  A006257-010816 If you are having technical difficulties with the website, please contact the website administrator by phone or email.  (503) 823-6040 or prrhelp@portlandoregon.gov

communications.subject: RE: Oregon Public Records Law Request #S283207-050923
communications.communication:
Hello please find my answers for the reasons for a fee waiver. 

You have requested a fee waiver from the City of Portland for the fees associated with your public records request.  The City requests the following information to evaluate your fee waiver request:

1) How do you or your organization intend to use the information?  (Please answer regarding the specific information requested as opposed to speaking generally regarding information on the general topic requested);

The emails obtained through this request may be used as the basis of an article on the ongoing deliberations about which gunshot detection firm to work with. 

2) How will the information benefit the wider public?  (Please explain how this specific information assists the public given the information already provided to the public on this topic);

We believe there is a strong public interest in reporting these matters, not least because Shotspotter/SoundThinking is a rapidly growing policing technology company on which hundreds of police departments rely and the company is working actively to secure a contract with the Portland Police Bureau. Because this is a public procurement process, the public has a strong interest in full transparency into this process and conversations that are happening between public officials such as the police and any vendors they are considering working with. 

3) How do you or your organization intend to disseminate the information to the wider public?

After reviewing the documents we will determine if they warrant coverage through some sort of journalistic work including but not limited to written articles, podcasts, or videos.

title: Timekeeping records for 2014 – 2023

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Timekeeping records for 2014 – 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

For a list of civil service title codes that follows, I request tabulations of headcount, timekeeping hours and attendance days for the years 2014–2023 (to latest date available). This should include any breakdown of attendance days by type (e.g., days in attendance, vacation, sick, etc.) as well as hours worked by type (e.g., overtime). 

The requested Title Codes are: 

70210
7021A
7021B
7021C
7021D
7021E
70235
7023A
7023B
70260
70265
7026A
7026B
7026C
7026D
7026E
7026F
70270
7027A

These correspond to Union Codes 17, 29, 59, 79, and 91

Records should be provided in a computer-readable tabular format (e.g., .CSV or Excel spreadsheet) where possible. If it is not possible, then provide the records as PDF's, preferably one generated from the computer terminal and not through printing-and-scanning.

In addition to these records, please also provide any data dictionary provided by the timekeeping software vendor.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

T. McElwee

title: Reports of Sexual Misconduct at State University of New York at Albany.

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Reports of Sexual Misconduct at State University of New York at Albany.
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Freedom of Information Act Officer
State University of New York at Albany
1400 Washington Avenue
Albany, NY 12222

Subject: Freedom of Information Act Request

Dear FOIA Officer,

I am submitting a request for information under the provisions of the New York State Freedom of Information Law (Article 6 of the Public Officers Law) from the State University of New York at Albany. My request pertains to reports, investigations, and litigation concerning incidents of sexual misconduct over the past five years.

I am specifically requesting access to the following categories of information:

Incident Reports: All incident reports or complaints of sexual misconduct involving students, including those filed by the students themselves or others on their behalf.
Investigation Outcomes: Detailed records of any investigations undertaken in response to these reports, including the findings (such as sustained, not founded, inconclusive, etc.), any actions taken by the university, and the outcomes of any subsequent appeals.
Litigation: Records of all litigation and court proceedings related to these incidents of sexual misconduct. This includes not only the cases initiated by the university or individual students but also any related court cases that support the premise that such information should be released under FOIA, such as case law establishing or affirming the public's right to access this type of information.
Policy Changes: Any revisions or amendments made to the university's policies, guidelines, or procedures concerning sexual misconduct over the last five years in response to these incidents.
As allowed under the New York State Freedom of Information Law, I request that these documents be produced on a rolling basis, meaning as they become available. Pursuant to New York State Public Officers Law § 89(3)(a), I ask that the State University of New York at Albany make a good faith effort to provide the records as they are located and reviewed, rather than waiting to release all records at once.

I am not requesting access to personally identifiable information or other confidential details that would infringe upon the privacy rights of individuals involved. Please redact such information in compliance with the law while still providing the relevant data about the incidents and their outcomes.

If any part of my request is denied, I kindly ask you to provide a written explanation citing the specific legal reasons for the denial. If any aspect of my request is unclear or needs further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact me

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

Dear FOIA Officer,

Under the provisions of the New York State Freedom of Information Law (Article 6 of the Public Officers Law), I am requesting access to and copies of documents from the State University of New York Maritime College. My request pertains to reports, investigations, and litigation concerning incidents of sexual misconduct over the past five years.

To make my request as clear as possible, I am specifically interested in the following categories of information:

Incident Reports: All incident reports or complaints of sexual misconduct involving students. This includes reports filed by the students themselves or others on their behalf.

Investigation Outcomes: Detailed records of any investigations undertaken in response to these reports, including the findings (such as sustained, not founded, inconclusive, etc.), any actions taken by the university, and the outcomes of any subsequent appeals.

Litigation: Records of all litigation and court proceedings related to these incidents of sexual misconduct. This includes not only the cases initiated by the university or individual students but also any related court cases that support the premise that such information should be released under FOIA, such as case law establishing or affirming the public's right to access this type of information.

Policy Changes: Any revisions or amendments made to the college's policies, guidelines, or procedures concerning sexual misconduct over the last five years in response to these incidents.

As allowed under the New York State Freedom of Information Law, I request that these documents be produced on a rolling basis, meaning as they become available. Pursuant to New York State Public Officers Law § 89(3)(a), I ask that the State University of New York Maritime College make a good faith effort to provide the records as they are located and reviewed, rather than waiting to release all records at once.
It is not my intention to request access to personally identifiable information or other confidential details that would infringe upon the privacy rights of individuals involved. Please redact such information in compliance with the law while still providing the relevant data about the incidents and their outcomes.

If any part of my request is denied, I kindly ask you to provide a written explanation citing the specific legal reasons for the denial. If any aspect of my request is unclear or needs further clarification, please do not hesitate to contact me

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: CB FBI 5.9.23
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

A prior request on records for Christopher Bird under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552 included partial or incorrect FBI case file numbers. Please find the amended request below:

I am requesting copies of all records, documents, and correspondence responsive to Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) case files 105-HQ-83543 and 123-HQ-15685. A prior Freedom of Information/Privacy Act (FOIPA) request, 1547783-000, was sent to the FBI for records on Christopher Bird (May 11, 1928-May 2, 1996), and the Bureau responded by identifying the aforementioned case file numbers as potentially responsive to the request and stating all subsequent records had been transferred to the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA). Further, it recommended the filing of a FOIPA request through NARA's Special Access and Freedom of Information Act Program. Therefore, I am sending this request for access to FBI case files 105-HQ-83543 and 123-HQ-15685.

If Mr. Bird is identified in these records, there is no expectation of a violation of his privacy, as he passed away in 1996. I have attached a reproduction of Mr. Bird's obituary, published in The New York Times on May 06, 1996.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please advise of which tier of processing queue this request falls under and an estimated time frame for processing.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

title: Prison Transfer Policy and Communications

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Prison Transfer Policy and Communications
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Documents pertaining to DOCCS policy or documentation about inter-prison transfers of incarcerated people (see below for a note about what is meant by “inter-prison transfers,” in case the term is unclear or does not align with DOCCS terminology). Specifically, I am requesting: 

1) All policies, procedures, memorandums of understanding, intergovernmental agreements, any other sort of agreement, and all related directive materials regarding the transfer of incarcerated persons between different facilities within New York state. 

2) From 1/1/2020 through 12/31/2021 specifically: all documents, papers, letters, email correspondence, memoranda, training materials, presentations, directives, guidance, press releases, or other communications (both internal and external) about transfers and COVID-19. This includes – but is not limited to – any memos, emails, or directives issued/produced in 2020 or 2021 that discuss transfer procedures and mention COVID-19, health precautions, and/or respiratory illness. It also includes (but is not limited to) any memos, emails, or directives issued/produced in 2020 or 2021 that discuss changes to the frequency of transfers in response to the virus (e.g., halting transfers, minimizing transfers, transferring at-risk incarcerated people, etc.). 

3) Any contracts or agreements regarding inter-prison transfers, including but not limited to a contract with a private transfer company, vehicle purchasing or leasing, and so on.

NOTE ON DEFINITION: By inter-prison transfer, I am referring to any non-temporary change in an incarcerated person’s housing facility. In other words, any movement of an incarcerated person that would change their “Housing/Releasing Facility,” as recorded in DOCCS’s “Incarcerated Lookup” database. This would include – but is not limited to – movements resulting from disciplinary proceedings (i.e., raised security level or other safety risks), movements to lower security facilities, transfers resulting from incarcerated person-initiated transfer requests, transfers preceding facility closure, and/or transfers to accommodate medical, program, or other needs. If the records provided refer to movements more broadly than this definition of transfers, that is acceptable and please send them. However, if there are records that refer ONLY to types of movements that would not include inter-prison transfers as defined here, they fall outside of this request. If there is any question about this, please feel free to reach out and I am happy to clarify.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Iolanthe Brooks

title: 2020-2021 Prison Transfer Records

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: 2020-2021 Prison Transfer Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Records of the number of transfers conducted by DOCCS in 2020 and 2021. I understand that this information might be collected in different ways and have outlined specific requests in relation to what I anticipate might be possible below. If none of the below is possible or if records pertinent to prison transfers (i.e., movements) are collected/saved in a way that I have not captured, please contact me with more information. I am flexible and can modify my request to be responsive to the records that exist.

REQUEST: 
I request information on movements/transfers between DOCCS facilities conducted between January 1, 2020, and December 31, 2021. This would include any non-temporary change in an incarcerated person’s housing facility. In other words, any movement of an incarcerated person that would change their “Housing/Releasing Facility” as listed on DOCCS's "Incarcerated Lookup," for example. This would include – but is not limited to – movements resulting from disciplinary proceedings (i.e., raised security level or other safety risks), movements to lower security facilities, transfers resulting from incarcerated person-initiated transfer requests, transfers preceding facility closure, and/or transfers to accommodate medical, program, or other needs. This would not include movements such as: a temporary transfer to a hospital for a medical procedure; a temporary transfer to court for a court appointment; or a one-night or few-hour “stop-over” at a DOCCS facility on the way to another facility. 

If movements/transfers are recorded in such a way as to distinguish movements that result in changes in housing facility from temporary movements, then I request records of every inter-facility, non-temporary (as described above) transfer made in 2020 and 2021. For each, I request the following insofar as is possible: 

a)	The name of the sending facility 
b)	The name of the receiving facility
c)	The date of the transfer
d)	The reason for transfer 
e)	Any transfer considerations, as recorded/described
f)	Any additional explanation of the causes for transfer, as recorded/described
g)	Unique identifier for each person transferred, if possible 

CONTINGENCIES: 
If transfers are not disaggregated between temporary movements and non-temporary movements, then I request the above information for all movements. 

However these records are available is acceptable, with the priority being records that include the information listed above (including if this means requesting multiple types of records). 

For example, if the information above is available in a summary table organized by day, week, month, or another unit of time, I request that summary table. Or, if it is available as redacted versions of transfer forms for each transfer, then I request those forms (such as form 8.6, “Transfer Referral,” KITSM86; or form 4.5.1 “Transfer Review,” KGNCM4B). In other words, I’m flexible with what is available based on DOCCS record-making and record-keeping systems. If the above is impossible, please contact me to discuss what is available.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Iolanthe Brooks

Thank you for submitting your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to
the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) via email to
foia@nara.gov.  We received your request on May 8, 2023.  Your request
concerns *documents on the impact of deep fake technology during combat
operations. This can be an email or any type of file relevant to 'deep
fake' technology.  Date: 01 January 2016 until 19 January 2021 Keywords CAN
include disruptive technology, deep fakes, and deep fake.   *

Our office handles FOIA and Privacy Act requests for NARA’s operational records
(records created by this agency).  Because your FOIA request is for records
that may be archival records (records created by or originated in a
different agency but that may have been transferred to the legal custody of
NARA), we are forwarding it by this email to our Office of Research
Services, Textual Reference (RR2RR) staff who handle FOIA requests for
textual archival records.

That office will assign your request a tracking number and respond directly
to you. In the future, if you need to follow up with that office directly,
please contact them at the address below, or electronically via email
(email is preferred).

National Archives and Records Administration
Research Services, Textual Reference Branch (RR2RR)
8601 Adelphi Road, Room 2400
College Park, MD 20740

Phone: 301-837-3091
Fax: 301-837-1752
Email: archives2reference@nara.gov

For your reference, a copy of your request is below.

Please visit our website at www.archives.gov/foia for further information
about making a FOIA request to NARA.  On our main website,
www.archives.gov, you
can learn more about the resources we offer to the public, and you can
access our online catalog.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and pursuant to guidance received from the
Office of Management and Budget (OMB), NARA had adjusted its normal
operations to balance the need of completing its mission-critical work
while also adhering to the recommended social distancing for the safety of
our staff. As a result of this re-prioritization of activities, you may
experience a delay in receiving a substantive response to your FOIA
request.  We apologize for this inconvenience and appreciate your
understanding and patience.

Sincerely,
Ashley A. Bryan

College Park, Maryland, 20740-6001

title: Re: Expedited Freedom of Information Act Request

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Re: Expedited Freedom of Information Act Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

This is an expedited request by the Brown Institute for Media Innovation, MuckRock, and the California Newsroom (“Brown Institute,”“MuckRock,” and “California Newsroom”) under the Freedom of Information Act (“FOIA”), 5 U.S.C. § 552, for all submitted, denied and confirmed exceptional events related to criteria pollutants in EPA Region 1. A partial list of Example Submissions, Demonstrations and EPA responses prepared under the 2016 Exceptional Events Rule has been publicly posted by the EPA here: https://www.epa.gov/air-quality-analysis/example-demonstrations-and-epa-responses-prepared-under-2016-exceptional

Document Request

We seek copies of the following records submitted to and prepared by the EPA Regional Office between September 30, 2016, through May 08, 2023:

1. All initial notification packages created by state, local, or tribal agencies now held by the EPA Regional Office. By this language, we intend to include emails or any other records of communication containing, for example, the potential date of event, relevant criteria pollutant, location, and potential regulatory decision affected (such as designation, classification, attainment determination, attainment date extension, or finding of SIP inadequacy leading to SIP call). An example of an Initial Notification Summary for PM2.5 from EPA Region 9 has been attached to this request.
2. Any acknowledgement or response from EPA to initial notifications or notification packages, as described in 40 C.F.R. 50.14 (Table 2).
3. All submissions of demonstrations of exceptional events related to criteria pollutants, as submitted by state, local, or federal authorities.
4. All subsequent responses and decisions communicated by the EPA, including approvals, denials or requests for more information, as described in 40 C.F.R. 50.14.

We request that all of these records be produced in their native electronic formats with any attached metadata included, so long as such electronic files can be opened using standard commercially available software. If the files cannot be produced in this manner, we request that records be produced in an alternative electronic format that is text-searchable. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(B)

Fee Waiver Request

A waiver of search and review fees is appropriate here because disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii) and 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(a), (b)(1)-(2), and because the request is not primarily in the Brown Institute, MuckRock, or California Newsroom’s commercial interest, 45 C.F.R.§§ 5.45(a), (b)(3)(ii).

Disclosure Is in the Public Interest

Disclosure of the requested information is likely to contribute significantly to the public understanding of the regulation of air pollution, which is harmful to human health. 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(b)(1). In particular, the requested information will shed light on exceptional events, a mechanism used by regulators to account for and exclude air pollution, information which is not “already in the public domain.” 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(b)(2)(i). As a nonprofit organization assisting other news media organizations on coverage of federal government policy, we have demonstrated our “ability and intention to effectively convey information to the public.” 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(b)(2)(ii).

Limitation of Fees

We are also entitled to a limitation of fees because we are a member of the news media. 45 C.F.R. § 5.53(b); 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II). Accordingly, even if our application for a waiver of all fees is denied, we are entitled to a limitation of fees. As a news media requester, we are “entitled to search time, review time, and up to 100 pages of duplication” and can be charged only duplication fees after the first 100 pages or its cost equivalent. 45 C.F.R. § 5.53(b). We request that the information be provided in its native electronic format, and thus there should be no duplication fees.

Request for Expedited Processing

We also ask that the information requested be disclosed on an expedited basis. Expedited processing is appropriate here because a “compelling need” exists for disclosure of the requested information. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(I). A compelling need exists when, with respect to a request made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information to the public, there is “an urgent need to inform the public about an actual or alleged Federal Government activity.” 45 C.F.R. §5.27(b)(2).

As a news organization, we are primarily engaged in disseminating information to the public. Over the last several years, wildfires have grown, and with them, so has pollution from particulate matter and ozone. Climate change is a significant factor in the understanding of five of the six criteria pollutants, and understanding how criteria pollution overall is excepted is crucial to public understanding of the management of health risks. The information requested thus concerns “a matter of exigency to the American public” and “the consequences of delaying a response would compromise a significant recognized interest.” Bloomberg, L.P. v. United States Food & Drug Admin., 500 F. Supp. 2d 371, 377 (S.D.N.Y. 2007) (quoting Al-Fayed v. C.I.A., 254 F.3d 300, 310 (D.C. Cir. 2001)).

Request for Explanation of Withholdings and Redactions

If this request is denied in whole or in part, please provide a reasonable description of any withheld materials and a justification for all such withholdings that includes reference to the specific FOIA exemptions authorizing withholding and specific reasons why such exemptions apply. 45 C.F.R. § 5.31. An agency shall withhold information only if “the agency reasonably foresees that disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption” or “disclosure is prohibited by law.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8)(A)(i). We therefore request that if the EPA determines that an exemption applies that it also provide specific reasons why disclosure would harm any interest protected by such exemption. An agency shall also “consider whether partial disclosure of information is possible whenever the agency determines that a full disclosure of a requested record is not possible” and “take reasonable steps necessary to segregate and release nonexempt information.” Id. 552(a)(8)(A)(ii). We therefore request that the EPA release all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material.

***

Thank you for your prompt attention to this request. If you have any questions or concerns about what we are seeking, please do not hesitate to contact us at the email address below. Pursuant to the applicable FOIA provision and departmental regulations, we expect a response regarding this request within the ten (10) working day time limit set by law. 45 C.F.R. § 5.27(c); 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(ii)(I).

Sincerely,

Brown Institute, MuckRock, and California Newsroom
℅ Brown Institute for Media Innovation
2950 Broadway
New York NY 10027


The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Dillon Bergin

If the files cannot be produced in this manner, we request that records be produced in an alternative electronic format that is text-searchable. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(3)(B) 

Fee Waiver Request 

A waiver of search and review fees is appropriate here because disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest under 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii) and 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(a), (b)(1)-(2), and because the request is not primarily in the Brown Institute, MuckRock, or California Newsroom’s commercial interest, 45 C.F.R.§§ 5.45(a), (b)(3)(ii). 

Disclosure Is in the Public Interest 

Disclosure of the requested information is likely to contribute significantly to the public understanding of the regulation of air pollution, which is harmful to human health. 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(b)(1). In particular, the requested information will shed light on exceptional events, a mechanism used by regulators to account for and exclude air pollution, information which is not “already in the public domain.” 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(b)(2)(i). As a nonprofit organization assisting other news media organizations on coverage of federal government policy, we have demonstrated our “ability and intention to effectively convey information to the public.” 45 C.F.R. § 5.54(b)(2)(ii). 

Limitation of Fees 

We are also entitled to a limitation of fees because we are a member of the news media. 45 C.F.R. § 5.53(b); 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II). Accordingly, even if our application for a waiver of all fees is denied, we are entitled to a limitation of fees. As a news media requester, we are “entitled to search time, review time, and up to 100 pages of duplication” and can be charged only duplication fees after the first 100 pages or its cost equivalent. 45 C.F.R. § 5.53(b). We request that the information be provided in its native electronic format, and thus there should be no duplication fees. 

Request for Expedited Processing 

We also ask that the information requested be disclosed on an expedited basis. Expedited processing is appropriate here because a “compelling need” exists for disclosure of the requested information. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(I). A compelling need exists when, with respect to a request made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information to the public, there is “an urgent need to inform the public about an actual or alleged Federal Government activity.” 45 C.F.R. §5.27(b)(2). 

As a news organization, we are primarily engaged in disseminating information to the public. Over the last several years, wildfires have grown, and with them, so has pollution from particulate matter and ozone. Climate change is a significant factor in the understanding of five of the six criteria pollutants, and understanding how criteria pollution overall is excepted is crucial to public understanding of the management of health risks. The information requested thus concerns “a matter of exigency to the American public” and “the consequences of delaying a response would compromise a significant recognized interest.” Bloomberg, L.P. v. United States Food & Drug Admin., 500 F. Supp. 2d 371, 377 (S.D.N.Y. 2007) (quoting Al-Fayed v. C.I.A., 254 F.3d 300, 310 (D.C. Cir. 2001)). 

Request for Explanation of Withholdings and Redactions 

If this request is denied in whole or in part, please provide a reasonable description of any withheld materials and a justification for all such withholdings that includes reference to the specific FOIA exemptions authorizing withholding and specific reasons why such exemptions apply. 45 C.F.R. § 5.31. An agency shall withhold information only if “the agency reasonably foresees that disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption” or “disclosure is prohibited by law.” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8)(A)(i). We therefore request that if the EPA determines that an exemption applies that it also provide specific reasons why disclosure would harm any interest protected by such exemption. An agency shall also “consider whether partial disclosure of information is possible whenever the agency determines that a full disclosure of a requested record is not possible” and “take reasonable steps necessary to segregate and release nonexempt information.” Id. 552(a)(8)(A)(ii). We therefore request that the EPA release all segregable portions of otherwise exempt material. 

*** 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this request. If you have any questions or concerns about what we are seeking, please do not hesitate to contact us at the email address below. Pursuant to the applicable FOIA provision and departmental regulations, we expect a response regarding this request within the ten (10) working day time limit set by law. 45 C.F.R. § 5.27(c); 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(ii)(I). 

Sincerely, 

Brown Institute, MuckRock, and California Newsroom 
℅ Brown Institute for Media Innovation 
2950 Broadway 
New York NY 10027 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Dillon Bergin 
  * Expedited Processing Original Justification:
					Request for Expedited Processing 

We also ask that the information requested be disclosed on an expedited basis. Expedited processing is appropriate here because a “compelling need” exists for disclosure of the requested information. 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(i)(I). A compelling need exists when, with respect to a request made by a person primarily engaged in disseminating information to the public, there is “an urgent need to inform the public about an actual or alleged Federal Government activity.” 45 C.F.R. §5.27(b)(2).

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Odexo Documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Files, documents, correspondence, memos, reports, photographs, and electronic surveillance records, that reference or pertain to the following entities:

- Odexo
- Odexo Inc.
- Odexo.com

Please conduct a thorough search of the FBI's main file records as well as any cross-reference records that may contain information related to Odexo, Odexo Inc., and Odexo.com. Additionally, I request that you perform an Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) search for any records related to these entities.

If any records are withheld in full or in part, please provide a detailed explanation for the exemption being claimed, along with an index of withheld records. If my request is denied in whole or in part, I request that you justify all deletions by reference to specific exemptions of the FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gabriel Garcia

title: KING COUNTY DIRECTORS ASSOCIATION – PUBLIC RECORDS POLITY AND PROCEDURES - May 8, 2023

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: KING COUNTY DIRECTORS ASSOCIATION – PUBLIC RECORDS POLITY AND PROCEDURES - May 8, 2023
communications.communication:
05-09-2023

VIA EMAIL: KRISTEN DESKIN SHRM-SCP - HUMAN RESOURCES MANAGER [KDESKIN@KCDA.ORG]

SUBJECT: Washington Public Records Act Request [RCW 42.56] - RECORDS AND WRITINGS regarding published and adopted agency policy and procedures

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act [RCW 42.56] I hereby request the following records:

1. I request any and all RECORDS AND WRITINGS regarding your agency procedures for the processing of public records requests.

2. I request any and all RECORDS AND WRITINGS regarding your publicly posted agency policy regarding the processing of public records requests.

3. I request a complete copy of your agency's posted RCW 42.56.040 Duty to publish procedures. Specifically, I request a copy of the following regarding your agency:

RCW 42.56.040 - Duty to publish procedures.

(1) Each state agency shall separately state and currently publish in the Washington Administrative Code and each local agency shall prominently display and make available for inspection and copying at the central office of such local agency, for guidance of the public:
(a) Descriptions of its central and field organization and the established places at which, the employees from whom, and the methods whereby, the public may obtain information, make submittals or requests, or obtain copies of agency decisions;
(b) Statements of the general course and method by which its operations are channeled and determined, including the nature and requirements of all formal and informal procedures available;
(c) Rules of procedure;
(d) Substantive rules of general applicability adopted as authorized by law, and statements of general policy or interpretations of general applicability formulated and adopted by the agency; and
(e) Each amendment or revision to, or repeal of any of the foregoing.
(2) Except to the extent that he or she has actual and timely notice of the terms thereof, a person may not in any manner be required to resort to, or be adversely affected by, a matter required to be published or displayed and not so published or displayed.

DEFINITION OF RECORDS AND WRITINGS

RECORDS AND WRITINGS as defined by RCW 42.56.010(4): any handwriting, typewriting, printing, photostating, photographing, and every other means of recording any form of communication or representation including, but not limited to, letters, words, pictures, sounds, or symbols, or combination thereof, and all papers, maps, magnetic or paper tapes, photographic films and prints, motion picture, film and video recordings, magnetic or punched cards, discs, drums, diskettes, sound recordings, and other documents including existing data compilations from which information may be obtained or translated.

PRODUCTION PROCESSING AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS

Please provide all electronic records in their native electronic format. Please do not instead create new records by printing electronic files then scanning and printing the newly scanned prints. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment to this email address.

NATIVE ELECTRONIC FORMAT

Please provide all identified public records in their NATIVE electronic format. Unless the records exist IN PAPER FORM ONLY, DO NOT instead create new records by printing native stored electronic files, then scanning and re-printing these newly scanned prints only to reproduce them in again in electronic production.

In this request the NATIVE ELECTORNIC FORMAT FOR EMAIL is Microsoft .pst file. Please produce the .pst file. If the .pst file cannot be produced please explain the reasons why.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act regarding RCW 42.56.120 - Charges for copying.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

title: CEASE AND DESISTS (Department of Homeland Security)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Mr Tabb, Mr Kable, & Mr Demers:
 
After significant research, the undersigned have determined that the DOJ and FBI are directly involved in the Targeted Individual Program, attacking civilians with psychological torture techniques, including stalking, gangstalking, harassment, and intimidation.
 
The undersigned represent the interests of more than 2,000 Targeted Individuals ("Non-Investigative Subjects").  We demand an explanation for these activities and compensation for pain, suffering, and illegal torture.  A similar letter has been sent to the Air Force Space Command in Colorado Springs, and the DHS.
 
As leaders in the DOJ and FBI, we demand that you immediately CEASE AND DESIST your illegal activities, including the use of government personnel and any external groups, which may also be participating.  Such operations are in violation of Article 32 of the Geneva Conventions (psychological torture) and numerous Federal & State laws.
 
This CEASE AND DESIST ORDER is to inform you that your conspiracy to commit torture, harassing, stalking, and intimidation actions are illegal and will not be tolerated. We demand that you immediately CEASE AND DESIST.  Should you continue to pursue these activities in violation of this CEASE AND DESIST ORDER, we will not hesitate to pursue further legal action against you.
 
You may have already violated numerous Federal laws, including:
 
-  18 U.S. Code § 2381;  Treason.
-  18 U.S. Code § 2340; (c) Conspiracy to commit torture.
-  18 U.S. Code § 2382;  Misprision of Treason.
-  18 U.S. Code § 2384;  Seditious Conspiracy.
-  18 U.S. Code § 2389;  Recruiting for service against the United States.
-  18 U.S. Code § 241;  Conspiracy to Deprive Constitutional Rights.
-  18 U.S. Code § 242;  Deprivation of Constitutional Rights.
-  18 USC § 2261A;  Interstate Stalking.
-  18 USC § 875(c);  Interstate Communications.
-  47 USC § 223(a)(1)(c);  Harassing Telephone Calls.
-  18 U.S. Code § 1961; Organized Crime Control Act of 1980. (RICO)
-  Numerous State laws concerning stalking & harassment.
 
Should you choose to continue your current activities, we will not hesitate to file complaints with Police Departments and publicly expose your ongoing criminal activity.
 
This letter does not constitute an exhaustive statement of our position, nor is it a waiver of any rights or remedies in this or any other related matter.   We insist on your immediate compliance, and expect a written response within two weeks.
 
Signed,
 
TargetedJustice.com

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

ANTHONY WAYNE PHIFER

title: DHA UBI 5.8.23

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DHA UBI 5.8.23
communications.communication:
Dear FOIA officer:

You are receiving this correspondence as a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. subsection 552. I am requesting the following:

Copies of records for award ID HT001122F0085, for a delivery order given to the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, LLC (UEI: C1HBCJ9RMBV3) in the research area of "SERVICES FOR PHYSICS-BASED MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND TEST FOR BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF UNCONVENTIONALLY ACQUIRED BRAIN INJURY." This contract was awarded by the Department of Defense through the Defense Health Agency on behalf of the United States Army Medical Research and Development Command and has an action date of September 13, 2022 . This request includes, but is not limited to:

- Correspondence

- Requests for Proposals

- Requests for Information

- Statements of Work

- Memorandum(s) of Understanding

- Letters of Interest

- Award Letters

- Task Letters

- Privacy Impact Assessments

- Invoices

- Purchase and/or Change Orders

- Project Budgets and/or Budget Proposals

- Evaluation Reports

- Presentations by the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, LLC and/or its parent entity, The Johns Hopkins Univeristy (UEI: FTMTDMBR29C7)

I am asking you waive any fees associated with this request. I am a member of the news media and request classification as such. My bylines, which include Creem Magazine, Covert Action Magazine, and the Geopolitical Economy Report, can be found in both print and electronic publications. Please take note of the Office of Management and Budget guidelines published March 27, 1987 (52 FR 10012) that include electronic publications and other nontraditional publishers as representatives of the news media.

A fee waiver is appropriate in situations where "disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of the government, and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester,” 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(iii). This request would contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations and activities of government with regard to its research into the physical effects of directed energy attacks, as currently there is a concern among the members of the media and the public about so-called anomalous health incidents.

Anomalous health incidents, also known as Havana Syndrome, are events occurring between 2016 and the present day that have resulted in a condition, or a series of related conditions, afflicting intelligence agents and diplomats working for the governments of the United States and Canada. In 2016, the Associated Press reported on a number of such incidents that happened in Cuba that led to the United States pulling staff from its embassy in that country. Since that time, anomalous health incidents have continued to generate media attention in major new outlets, with stories focusing on the national security implications appearing in the New York Times and The New Yorker, among many other publications. Speculation presently focuses on the use of directed energy weapons, or ranged weapons that attack a target with electromagnetic radiation like ultra-high frequency radio waves, as one possible cause for anomalous health incidents.

As of 2023, there have been over 200 reported anomalous health incidents, with many of the victims stating they were subject to attacks by directed energy weapons. Given that most of these individuals have been identified as high-ranking officials across multiple federal agencies, any programs that may be investigating anomalous health incidents and/or the effects of directed energy on humans would be the subject of considerable public interest. This is especially important in light of the fact that both Congress and the President approved compensation in the range of $140,000 or $187,000 per person to individuals diagnosed as suffering from anomalous health incidents under the HAVANA Act of 2021.

Additionally, the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, LLC has been awarded contracts or grants covering similar research areas by the Department of Defense; award IDs N0002420F8124 and N0002421F8162 are active with the Naval Sea Systems Command as of May 2023 for work on "directed energy bio effects." This request would contribute to public understanding of how the government is handling research on anomalous health incidents and unconventionally acquired brain injuries.

In the event that there are fees, I am willing to pay up to $100. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

This request is not being made for commercial purposes. All documents will be provided to the general public without charge.

I look forward to your response within 20 working days, as the statute requires. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Sincerely,

Robert Skvarla, Jr.

title: All of the video exhibits presented at the Odin Lloyd murder trial.

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: All of the video exhibits presented at the Odin Lloyd murder trial.
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Hello, on the 17th of June 2013 at around 2:15 am Aaron Hernandez was questioned by police officers at the North Attenborough police station regarding the murder of MR Odin Lloyd. After this interview he was seen on CCTV just outside of the police station in a car. The CCTV footage then showed Aaron breaking his phone and collecting a new phone from his lawyer. This footage was then shown at his trial.

If possible could you send me all of the video and photo evidence that was presented at the Odin Lloyd murder trial? For example footage of Aaron at a gas station before the murder, footage of Odin Lloyd being picked up by Aaron as well as footage of Aaron arriving home with a gun on him.

I also kindly ask for the footage of his police interview as well as the CCTV footage of him breaking his phone.

All in all I’d like every single video exhibit that was presented at the Odin Lloyd trial.



The reason I am asking for all of this is because I believe that there are important life lessons to be learned from this appalling crime.

Thank you for your time.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Nadim Saleh

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: All of the video exhibits presented at the Odin Lloyd murder trial.
communications.communication:
Hello,
The Hernandez video files are approximately 20 gigabytes.  Please send us a thumb drive, and I will put the files on the thumb drive and send it back to you. There will be no charge for this.

Thank you,

Mark Ferriera,
Assistant Clerk/Magistrate
